case_name: Income Tax Officer v. India Fisheries P Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 211 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 22, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Miscellaneous Application No. 352 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February ,22, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Miscella

facts.text: Certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay under Art. 133(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is in pursuant to a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court of Maharashtra at Bombay under Art. 133 1  c of the Constitution

facts.text: India Fisheries Pvt Ltd was a private limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The India Fisheries  P  Ltd. hereinafter called the respondent was a private limited companypany

facts.text: Bombay High Court ordered winding up of India Fisheries Pvt Ltd on October 11, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and was directed to be wound up by an order of the Bombay High Court, dated October 11, 1950, and a Court Liquidator was appointed

facts.text: Court Liquidator appointed as Official Liquidator with powers under s.179 of Companies Act 1913.

anchor.surface_text: a Court Liquidator was appointed as the Official Liquidator thereof with all powers under s. 179 of the Indian Companies Act. 1913  VII of 1913  to be exercised by him under s. 180

facts.text: For assessment year 1948-49, respondent assessed on December 8, 1950, tax Rs. 8,737/15/-

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1948-49, the respondent was assessed on December 8. 1950, the tax being assessed at Rs. 8,737/15/-

facts.text: Income Tax Officer lodged claim for tax with Official Liquidator on or about March 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: . On or about March 15. 1951, the Income Tax Officer lodged a claim in respect of this tax with the Official Liquidator.

facts.text: Claim adjudged and allowed as ordinary claim and certified on April 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: That claim was adjudged and allowed as an ordinary claim and certified as such on April 2 1952.

facts.text: In August 1954, Official Liquidator declared dividend of 9 1/2 annas in a rupee.

anchor.surface_text: in August, 1954, the Official Liquidator declared a dividend of 9 1/2 annas in a rupee and paid to the Income Tax Department

facts.text: Paid to Income Tax Department Rs. 5,188/3/- against the claim.

anchor.surface_text: and paid to the Income Tax Department a sum of Rs. 5,188/3/- against the claim made by the Income Tax Officer as an ordinary creditor.

facts.text: Balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- remained payable to Income Tax Department.

anchor.surface_text: Thus a balance of Rs. 3,549/12 still remained payable to the Income Tax Department from the assets of the respondent.

facts.text: For year 1955-56, Department made demand on June 22, 1954 for Rs. 2,565/6/- as advance tax.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1955-56, the Department made a demand from the respondent on June 22, 1954, for a sum of Rs. 2,565/6/- as advance tax.

facts.text: Advance tax paid by Official Liquidator.

anchor.surface_text: This was paid by the Official Liquidator.

facts.text: Regular assessment for 1955-56: Rs. 1,126/12/- assessed as payable.

anchor.surface_text: On a regular assessment being made for the said year, only Rs. 1,1 26/12/was assessed as payable by the respondent.

facts.text: After adjusting advance payment, Rs. 1,460/1/- refundable inclusive of interest.

anchor.surface_text: After adjusting this sum against the advance payment of Rs. 2,565/6/-, Rs. 1,460/1/became refundable to the respondent, inclusive of interest.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer set off the refund amount against balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: Instead refunding the said balance to the respondent, the Income Tax Officer set off the said amount against the balance of Rs. 3,549/12/which was still outstanding

facts.text: Respondent filed revision petition to Commissioner of Income-tax, rejected on September 21, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a revision petition to the Commissioner of Income-tax, but the said petition was rejected by the Commissioner on September 21. 1959.

facts.text: Commissioner held action justified under s.49E of Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the action of the Income Tax Officer was perfectly justified under the provision of s. 49E of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: On November 25, 1959, respondent filed petition under Art. 226 praying for writ to set aside orders.

anchor.surface_text: On November 25, 1959, the respondent filed a petition under art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed for a writ, direction or order for setting aside the orders of the Income Tax Officer and the Income Tax Commissioner.

facts.text: High Court set aside orders of set off and directed Income Tax Officer to deal with refund under s.48.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accordingly set aside the orders passed by the Department in so far as they set off the amount of the refund towards the tax remaining payable, and directed the Income Tax Officer to deal with and dispose of the claim of the present respondent for the refund and pass appropriate orders in respect of the said amount of refund under the provisions of s. 48 of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court and holds Income Tax Officer erred in applying s.49E.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due.
under Art. 133 1  c of the Constitution is directed against the judgment

issues.text: whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: It is not denied by the learned Additional Solicitor-General that the State has no priority in respect of this claim. The question then arises whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 49E of the Income Tax Act. In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was not available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/-

The High Court observed that this claim thereafter was governed by the provisions of the Company law

arguments.claim: s.229 applies insolvency rules mandating pari passu payment to unsecured creditors

anchor.surface_text: Section 229 provides Application of insolvency rules in winding up of insolvent companypanies.- In the winding up of an insolvent companypany the same rules shall prevail and be observed with regard to the respective rights of secured and unsecured creditors

arguments.claim: Once debt proved in liquidation, Department cannot use s.49E to gain priority over other unsecured creditors

anchor.surface_text: The effect of these statutory provisions is, inter alia, that an unsecured creditor must prove his debts and all unsecured debts are to be paid pari passu. Therefore, once the claim of the Department has to be proved and is proved in the liquidation proceedings, the Department cannot by exercising the right under s. 49E

anchor.surface_text: If we were to read s. 49E in the way suggested by the learned Additional Solicitor-General, it would be defeating the very object underlying ss. 228 and 229 of the Companies Act, 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due.

anchor.surface_text: the effect of these statutory provisions is, inter alia, that an unsecured creditor must prove his debts and all unsecured debts are to be paid pari passu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct effect of ss.228 and 229 in insolvent company winding up; Department cannot circumvent via s49E

anchor.surface_text: If there is an apparent conflict between two independant provisions of law, the special provision must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.228/229 special for liquidation prevail over general s49E; applied to reconcile statutes

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order. The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction. But if we interpret s. 49E as we have done, it is a clear case of lack of jurisdiction. At any rate, there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: Section 49E of the Income Tax Act. In our opinion, therefore. the provision of Section 49E was number available to the Department for setting off the amount of the excess towards the balance of its claim of Rs. 8,737/15/-

Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order. The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction. But if we interpret s. 49E as we have done, it is a clear case of lack of jurisdiction. At any rate, there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: It is not denied by the learned Additional Solicitor-General that the State has no priority in respect of this claim. The question then arises whether s. 49E is subject to the Insolvency Rules contained in the Companies Act.

Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order. The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction. But if we interpret s. 49E as we have done, it is a clear case of lack of jurisdiction. At any rate, there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.

edges.explanation: Holding limits s.49E to cases where insolvency rules do not apply, constraining the concept's non-applicability in liquidation

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 49E can be reconciled with ss. 228 and 229 by holding that s. 49E applies when insolvency rules do number apply.

Accordingly, agreeing with the High Court, we hold that the Income Tax Officer was in error in applying s. 49E and setting off the refund due. The Commissioner was equally in error in affirming this order. The learned Additional Solicitor-General also urged that the application under art. 226 was misconceived because the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction. But if we interpret s. 49E as we have done, it is a clear case of lack of jurisdiction. At any rate, there is an error apparent on the face of the orders and the High Court was quite right in exercising its jurisdiction under Art. 226.
